body: Looks good. +1
Nick - I have a pr on your branch with an attempt to fix some of these, although it may be a couple of days out of date
Oh, I did not see that, thanks. I will resolve merge conflicts.

I totally forgot about this.  Looking over this again, I am a little ambivalent about this PR.  

I did as an experiment. I thought it would be cool, if parameter handling could be taken care of auto-magically.  I wanted to just specify the parameters that I need via the annotation and have some shared logic perform parameter handling and validation, along with enhancing the docs.  Seems more DRY-ish and all that.

As this stands, I don't think it is very useful.  Different functions want to handle required params in different ways.  Sometimes an exception is thrown, sometime a value is returned like NaN, etc.  This doesn't give you any flexibility in how to respond to missing params.   There are probably a few other things that need to be covered before this is close to being useful.

I would be interested in opinions on this though.  Maybe with input from others this could become useful.  But right now, I am a -1 on this.

@mmiklavc Looks like https://github.com/apache/incubator-metron/pull/362 for METRON-575 got pulled in yesterday. Could you either kick this PR to get it to rerun and hopefully run correctly, or just merge in master so that Travis runs as expected?
Kicking
Opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-12959 for Apache Infra to close this PR.
Is that failure legit?
I am trying to figure out why it is failing in Travis.  When I run it locally, it works just fine.
I will give it a try
were you planning on sync'ing with master?
Oops.  I thought I had pushed that out.  Maybe that is the problem.  Thanks
@ottobackwards That refactoring look like what you were looking for?

yes, that looks consistent, if you can think of an improvement however, I'm all ears.
I do have a question - but I'll put it inline
another point with all the process runner stuff.... there is a LOT of repeated code through out the tests.  I might give a thought to how to get some re-usable boilerplate in there
worked locally for me as well.

I completely agree about the code duplication (and a lot of dead code like unused fields and params)  throughout the tests, and was thinking about throwing a ticket in for cleaning up some of that code.  I can go ahead and create it if you want, otherwise if you're going to take a look and have some ideas I can let you throw it up and fill it with your thoughts.  Preference?
Needed sync'd with master.  Working now.  Yay.

What I'm looking at is the Processor interface implementations and seeing if that can be reduced by providing some same base and derivation ( like the ES and Solr processor code is the same just about ).  I'm not looking as much at cleanup as refactoring to make it easier to do standard testing things.  If I understand what you are looking for, there would be two jiras.
I will throw up a jira for that refactoring, if you want to add one for the type of cleanup you are looking at you do that one
Sounds like a plan. Anything else on this PR?
METRON-587 if you want to put $.02 in.
No - how can I test this?  Just run the tests?

Yep, it's all tied into the integration test.  Travis output of the test from the check is actually at:
https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-metron/builds/178028223#L492, and you can see the errors getting kicked out, but the test still passing.
+1, looks good!
ok .  But just to mention it - you are going to have to refactor from master based on the changes I made to the components etc.  can you re-sync master etc?  I'll test that can give you the sign off

You mean from https://github.com/apache/incubator-metron/pull/344? I already fixed the conflicts from it.

I can merge master back in again if you want, but the only commits in master and not my branch appear to be:
METRON-584 STELLAR should have a TO_LONG Function (ottobackwards) closes apache/incubator-metron#368
METRON-575 State from different profiles can be co-mingled incorrectly (nickwallen) closes apache/incubator-metron#362

sorry, my mistake
i'll run this right away

Justin - if you look at the WriteBoltIntegrationTest in the processor - I had attempted to read from error and invalid queues - I don't think what is in there is correct base on this pr, can you take a peek?
But the topics are correct?
+1 reviewed and tests run

Thanks a lot for reviewing this, Otto.  

Regarding the WriterBoltIntegrationTest, the topics looks good.  I had to do a bit of digging to confirm them, because I didn't realize they're kinda hidden in ParserTopologyBuilder, but it looks like ENRICHMENT_TOPIC, DEFAULT_PARSER_INVALID_TOPIC, and DEFAULT_PARSER_ERROR_TOPIC are what you want and what you have.

The reason this PR differs is because enrichment is specifically managed by the test.yaml, so the way components get hooked up is different and required me to define bolts to actually write the errors to Kafka topics.

Ended up making a few additional changes here. First, got rid of the /apps/metron/enrichment directory entirely. With indexing being split off into its own topology, this no longer made sense to live there. Furthermore, "indexed" was the only thing that lived in the enrichment directory in hdfs. The indexed doc path will now live in /apps/metron/indexing/indexed to keep consistent with the dir structure we used in the past. In addition, I've now exposed the directory as a property the user can both see and modify in the advanced properties section in Ambari.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/658443/20577395/4931cdd0-b17f-11e6-94e6-659ba134837e.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/658443/20577407/5d5f0f2a-b17f-11e6-9036-5202af5a3252.png)

Lastly, I updated the quickdev environment to reflect this change as well.
+1 on inspection
Makes sense, +1. Thanks!
Any other feedback guys?  Just waiting on +1s if you guys are happy with the change.

+1 by inspection

Updated the root pom's maven-compiler-version to match what it was.  Also noticed that the overridden versions in child poms tend to use 3.1.  Does anyone know if that's intentional, or just an artifact of moving chunks of poms around?  If it is intentional, that's a reason to keep them separate.  I was able to package things up (admittedly skipping tests) with 3.5.1 without issues.
I'm +1 on this, good stuff. @justinleet - you still gtg with the additional changes?
Good catch. Thanks!  +1 by inspection, pending CI build
Yep, I'm +1, too.
Re-Run travis - build working locally

Sorry for the delayed response, @cestella - I was taking some time off for the holiday.

While I don't believe custom enrichment is pushing us over the timeout (we've clocked it at 15ms at the worst), that's certainly a possibility and something that we should also guard against. With this in mind, we now have two tasks to look into:
1. Ensuring all messages get acked after a successful join by building out the `streamMessageMap`
2. Making sure that our cache refresh is set to some fraction of the Storm timeout interval

Are these both items that we would like to complete? Should we split these into separate JIRAs and PRs? Should I work on the acking changes within this PR?

Yep, so my personal suggestion is to make sure that all messages get acked on a successful join by augmenting `streamMessageMap` and ensure that the cache refresh is *longer* than the storm timeout (if it is shorter, then it'll never join because the partial messages will timeout before the final message comes through).

Anyone else have thoughts?

+1 (travis pending), glad to see the end of those. 
One small nit- if you find yourself doing wholesale dependency versioning, would you consider using the dependencyManagement section in the top-level pom?
On the warning/failure deal, does [this](http://maven.apache.org/plugins/maven-dependency-plugin/examples/failing-the-build-on-dependency-analysis-warnings.html) do what you're looking for?

Looks like the build failed for a completely unrelated test. The latest commit in master fails the build on the same test.

Should I wait until that is fixed and then merge master into my branch?
@nickwallen somehow this fix failed a profiler test. can you take a look?

On the dependency versioning, it is a good idea to use the dependencyManagement section, but I'd probably consider that cleanup out of scope for this ticket. I didn't want to start a larger refactor here, just clear out the warnings.

On point two, it's related, but different.  We should fix our issues with that (to see them run ```mvn dependency:analyze```) also.  The difference is that your link covers dependency issues, but I'm interested in general pom issues (e.g. using the deprecated variable).

I'm also inclined to consider point two more important, partially because I don't want to generalize a bunch of dependencies that end up not actual being general anyway if they're unused. Any objections to that plan?

I'm inclined to create two follow up tickets, one for each of them.  I'm happy to pick up the second one, given that it's pretty related to this ticket.

No objections- a caveat though. I was referring to the changes you made around the maven-jar-plugin, which now that I typed it I realize is a plugin, so please %s/dependency/plugin my earlier comment. That said, if you want to open a JIRA for the pom refactoring, that'd be great! :)

Definitely seems to be some kind of sporadic failure with those integration tests.  For now, close and reopen the PR and it would likely fix it. 

I created a JIRA to track the sporadic failures.   I have yet to be able to replicate this locally. Sorry, I know these sporadic failures are annoying.  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/METRON-597
I think you should >fetch apache && merge apache/master && push origin METRON-FOO  ( the equiv. for your repo obviously )
Kicking Travis due to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/METRON-597
can this be done in the pom/surefire?
Dunno.  What are the advantages to doing it that way?
Configuration only change.  So, let's say that there is another pr that changes that test, it can do so without worrying about the commented out code etc.  not a big deal,  really just curious
Agreed, this should be changed in the pom.  http://maven.apache.org/surefire/maven-surefire-plugin/examples/inclusion-exclusion.html

Doesn't this conflict with the merge requirements on the draft [Coding Guidelines](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=61332235) page?  Specifically:
* A patch that breaks tests, or **introduces regressions by changing or removing existing tests** should not be merged. Tests must always be passing on master. This implies that the tests have been run...

I understand the current scenario means this isn't straightforward - perhaps that's an indication that the dev guidelines need updated to account for exceptions?  Or maybe we take another tact to fix the issue.  I'll shoot an email to the current [DISCUSS] thread regarding this.
Would it be worth closing/reopening a PASSING PR to see if it too fails?

Alternatively, if you wanted a one-liner, I think you could @Ignore the test class.

I didn't see @JonZeolla - add to the [DISCUSS] thread, so I'll answer here- I don't agree that this introduces a regression, it corrects one. At some point, something was introduced that has a damaging interaction with this test. As a result, the build is broken. I'd agree that we cannot introduce any Profiler changes until we get this sorted, but I don't see a problem with disabling the broken test as it is unrelated to any code changes to the classes under test.

@dlyle65535 while we slightly disagree on semantics, I agree that this should move forward for the short term.  I'm primarily indicating that the dev guide needs updated to account for situations like this.  I sent an email out to the [DISCUSS] thread a couple of minutes back.
@JonZeolla - oh yeah, totally in agreement there.
Probably a dumb question, but doesn't integration-test run Failsafe?
Thanks for this change, @JonathanRider - can you tell me how you tested it?
This still runs locally, and appears to just incredibly unluckily be breaking.  If this one fails, I'm going to wait to pull in https://github.com/apache/incubator-metron/pull/380.

Just realized we had some custom code since we couldn't get the List object working for feeding in multiple IP's. So I added in the code so you can just have a comma separated list of IP's. 

We have a dev cluster that has 3 master nodes, but I only gave the writer 2 ip addresses. I sent data through, then stopped the elasticsearch service on that machine. Sent data through and it works (previously this would give a NoNodeAvailable exception). I then started ES back up on that server, and shut down the ES Service on the other server and sent data through again and it also works.

@nickwallen This seems to pretty consistently failing the ProfilerIntegrationTest on Travis (not local, unfortunately), if you're looking for something seemingly repeatable.

Could you glance at this to see if I'm doing something that has an unexpected affect on the test? All I've really done is bumped the maven-jar-plugin version, removed an unrelated dependency, and migrated from a deprecated variable in an unrelated pom.

Thanks @justinleet.  I do not see anything you've done here that would cause any problems.  

I am able to fairly reliably reproduce the bug from METRON-597 when run in Travis CI.  So maybe this isn't more likely to happen with the changes that you've made, than any others.
Travis is sleepy.  Hasn't started the build.  Kick.

I believe that #381 is the real solution to this problem.  This PR being simply a work around.  I would prefer to push #381 and close this PR.  

Open to other's opinions though.  Still need some votes to do anything.
Is there anything else I need to do in order to get this merged in, @dlyle65535 ?

After 3 4 commits we might finally have something sensible. :)

Iteration is protected by a defensive copy.  Adding Puts is protected by the synchronizedList which explicitly synchronizes on a mutex for an operation like `add`.
@nickwallen Sounds reasonable, once #381 gets fleshed out.
I think you closed the wrong one
I was not happy with #381 . I will reopen it soon once I have a fix that I am happy with.
Could you give it a run up on Quick Dev using your patch rebased on master?

Just ran it on quickdev where I set the es.host in the global json file to "node2,node1" where node2 doesn't exist as it is a single node vagrant.

Using my patch, it writes to ES without a problem as it fails to use node2, so it switches to node1.

I then compiled master and did the same thing and received this error since node2 doesn't exist and it fails to use the second host.:
2016-12-01 21:41:18.942 o.a.m.w.BulkWriterComponent [ERROR] Failing 5 tuples
org.elasticsearch.client.transport.NoNodeAvailableException: None of the configured nodes are available: [{#transport#-1}{10.120.164.190}{node2/10.120.164.190:9300}]
